instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study of the discrimination of grass-fed versus non grass-fed milks?
What spectral feature processing methods were used to discriminate between grass-fed and non grass-fed milks?
Output: Linear discriminant analysis and PLS-DA were used to discriminate between grass-fed and non grass-fed milks.

instruction: What metric was chosen to measure the accuracy of the prediction models in the related study of the discrimination of grass-fed versus non grass-fed milks?
Output: ##The text does not specify the specific metric that was chosen to measure the accuracy of the prediction models.

instruction: What were the criteria used to evaluate the robustness, specificity, and accuracy of the machine-learning statistical analysis methods in discriminating between grass-fed and non grass-fed milks based on mid-infrared (MIR) spectra?
Output: The criteria used to evaluate the robustness, specificity, and accuracy of the machine-learning statistical analysis methods in discriminating between grass-fed and non grass-fed milks based on mid-infrared (MIR) spectra were not explicitly mentioned in the given text.

instruction: Can the linear discriminant analysis and partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA) methods used in the related study be considered superior to traditional methods for discriminating between grass-fed and non grass-fed milks based on mid-infrared (MIR) spectra?
Output: Yes, the linear discriminant analysis and partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA) methods used in this study can be considered superior to traditional methods for discriminating between grass-fed and non grass-fed milks based on mid-infrared (MIR) spectra. These machine-learning statistical analysis methods demonstrated a greater level of accuracy for predicting cow diet from MIR spectra compared to traditional methods such as auditing and inspection of farm records.
